title: DNS Spoofing and Lightning Notes Transfer Experiment
excerpt: An exploration into Android's Termux tools, culminating in an experimental, lightning-fast LAN note transfer system via DNS spoofing.
author: Codem
content:
Termux Explorations: DNS Spoofing & Fast LAN Notes

Since building a push notifications Flask server on my phone using Termux, I became curious about the further capabilities of the Android terminal. Investigating various tools revealed some that were quite interesting and potentially dangerous if misused.

The Experiment

My goal was to create a lightning-fast note transfer system over my local area network (LAN) as an experiment to better understand DNS spoofing and Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) concepts.

The core of the system involves using dnsmasq for DNS spoofing. This is configured to route ALL domain requests from the target device (my laptop) to a single, dedicated HTML page hosted on my phone.

This HTML page acts as the interface for note transfer. Any text entered into the input field on my laptop is immediately logged into a text file on my phone.

This results in a janky but remarkably effective method for transferring small notes and snippets of text between devices on the same LAN.

Next Steps

I plan to expand this experiment by looking into incorporating Text-to-Speech (TTS) capabilities and developing a more robust file transfer system.
